definition:
A manifold structure embedded in a higher-dimensional ConceptualSpace
   or EmbeddingSpace on which data or activations approximately lie
   (e.g. low-dimensional manifold of natural text states).
opposite_reasoning: ConceptManifold is a highly technical geometric/topological concept with no natural linguistic antonym. The best opposition for Fisher-LDA steering would contrast the core properties: continuous vs. discrete, structured vs. unstructured, low-dimensional organization vs. high-dimensional scatter. DiscretePointCloud captures this opposition most directly - it represents data that lacks the smooth, continuous, low-dimensional structure that defines a manifold. For AI safety applications, distinguishing manifold-structured representations (organized concepts) from unstructured noise could be valuable for detecting when models are operating in well-learned vs. poorly-understood regions of concept space. While this term doesn't exist in standard ontologies, it's a principled technical opposite worth adding.
